elements.content: Seven new coordination polymers {[Cu3(tib)4](NO3)6·4.94H2O} n (1), {[Cu2(tib)2(SO4)2]·2EtOH·2H2O} n (2), [Cu(tib)Cl2] n (3), {[Cd(tib)2](NO3)2·4H2O} n (4), {[Cd(tib)(H2O)2(SO4)]·EtOH·H2O} n (5) {[Co(tib)(H2O)2(SO4)]·EtOH·H2O} n (6), and {[Ni(tib)(H2O)2(SO4)]·EtOH·H2O} n (7) (EtOH = ethanol) were prepared by reactions of flexible tripodal ligand 1,3,5-tris(imidazol-1-ylmethyl)benzene (tib) with the corresponding metal salts. Their structures were determined by X-ray crystallography. The different structures of 1−3 as well as 4 and 5 indicate that the counteranions play an important role in the construction of coordination polymers. The distinct structures of Cu(II) and Cd(II) complexes with the same counteranion demonstrate that the metal centers with different coordination geometry have a significant influence on the structures. The same 1D chain structure of 5−7 indicated that the metal centers with the same octahedral coordination geometry do not affect the structure of the complexes. On the other hand, ligand tib acts as a three-connecting linker to connect three M(II) centers with different conformations. In 1, two different conformations (cis, trans, trans -, and trans -) of tib coexist. In 2−4, tib adopts the cis, trans, trans-conformation, while in the case of 5−7, tib has the cis, cis, cis-conformation. The results attest that the flexible tripodal ligand tib can adopt different conformations to form complexes with varied structures. Furthermore, the reversible anion exchange properties of 1 and 4 were studied.

The influences of counteranion and coordination geometry of metal center on the structure of the complexes were discussed. The reversible anion exchange properties of the complexes were reported.

elements.content: The rational design and assembly of metal−organic frameworks (MOFs) has been flourishing in recent years and received remarkable attention not only due to their intriguing framework structure but also because of their interesting properties and potential applications in optical, electronic, and magnetic fields, gas storage, ion exchange, selective guest inclusion, and catalysis. A great number of MOFs with various structures have been reported to date; nevertheless, it is still a great challenge to predict and exactly control the structures and compositions of the frameworks. One of the most efficient strategies to construct MOFs is to employ multidentate organic ligands to link suitable metal centers into infinite framework. According to the previously reported studies, tripodal ligands with arene core have been found to be one of the most useful organic building blocks for the construction novel coordination frameworks. Complexes with specific structures and interesting properties have been obtained by reactions of suitable metal salts with rigid or flexible tripodal ligands, such as 1,3,5-tricyanobenzene, 2,4,6-tris(4-pyridyl)-1,3,5-triazine, 1,3,5-benzenetribenzoate, benzene-1,3,5-triacetate, 1,3,5-tris(4-pyridylmethyl)benzene, 1,3,5-tris(benzimidazole-1-ylmethyl)-2,4,6-trimethylbenzene, 1,3,5-tris(pyrazol-1-ylmethyl)- 2,4,6-triethylbenzene, and N,N′,N′′-tris(3-pyridinyl)-1,3,5-benzenetricarboxamide. Among them, the rigid ligands have few or even no conformational changes when they react with metal salts, while the flexible ligands can adopt varied conformations and coordination modes according to the different geometric requirements of the metal ions and as a result may offer MOFs with different structures.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The rational design and assembly of metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) has been flourishing in recent years and received remarkable attention not only due to their intriguing framework structure but also because of their interesting properties and potential applications in optical, electronic, and magnetic fields, gas storage, ion exchange, selective guest inclusion, and catalysis. A great number of MOFs with various structures have been reported to date; nevertheless, it is still a great challenge to predict and exactly control the structures and compositions of the frameworks. One of the most efficient strategies to construct MOFs is to employ multidentate organic ligands to link suitable metal centers into infinite framework. According to the previously reported studies, tripodal ligands with arene core have been found to be one of the most useful organic building blocks for the construction novel coordination frameworks. Complexes with specific structures and interesting properties have been obtained by reactions of suitable metal salts with rigid or flexible tripodal ligands, such as 1,3,5-tricyanobenzene, 2,4,6-tris(4-pyridyl)-1,3,5-triazine, 1,3,5-benzenetribenzoate, benzene-1,3,5-triacetate, 1,3,5-tris(4-pyridylmethyl)benzene, 1,3,5-tris(benzimidazole-1-ylmethyl)-2,4,6-trimethylbenzene, 1,3,5-tris(pyrazol-1-ylmethyl)- 2,4,6-triethylbenzene, and N,N',N''-tris(3-pyridinyl)-1,3,5-benzenetricarboxamide. Among them, the rigid ligands have few or even no conformational changes when they react with metal salts, while the flexible ligands can adopt varied conformations and coordination modes according to the different geometric requirements of the metal ions and as a result may offer MOFs with different structures.

elements.content: We focus our attention on the construction of MOFs with imidazole-containing tripodal ligands, for example 1,3,5-tris(1-imidazolyl)benzene, 1,3-bis(1-imidazolyl)-5-(imidazol-1-ylmethyl)benzene, 1-(1-imidazolyl)-3,5-bis(imidazol-1-ylmethyl)benzene, 1,3,5-tris(imidazol-1-ylmethyl)-2,4,6-trimethylbenzene (titmb), and 2,4,6-tris[4-(imidazol-1-ylmethyl)phenyl]-1,3,5-triazine. The results showed that the self-assembly procedures and the structures of the resulted complexes with flexible tripodal ligand are influenced by many factors such as the geometric requirement of the metal ions, counteranions, the ratio of ligand to metal ion, and solvent system. This encouraged us to undertake further studies to elucidate and understand the details of the assembly process of the flexible tripodal ligand with metal salts and the influence factors on the structure of the MOFs. Herein, we report the syntheses and crystal structures of seven coordination polymers, {[Cu3(tib)4](NO3)6·4.94H2O} n (1), {[Cu2(tib)2(SO4)2]·2EtOH·2H2O} n (2), [Cu(tib)Cl2] n (3), {[Cd(tib)2](NO3)2·4H2O} n (4), {[Cd(tib)(H2O)2(SO4)]·EtOH·H2O} n (5) {[Co(tib)(H2O)2(SO4)]·EtOH·H2O} n (6), and {[Ni(tib)(H2O)2(SO4)]·EtOH·H2O} n (7), obtained by reactions of flexible tripodal ligand 1,3,5-tris(imidazol-1-ylmethyl)benzene (tib) with corresponding metal salts. The results attest that the flexible ligand tib can adopt different conformations and act as tridentate connector to form complexes with varied structures. According to the position of three imidazole groups relative to the central benzene ring plane, three different conformations (Scheme ) of tib were defined, namely the cis, trans, trans-one: three imidazole groups of tib ligand distribute on the two sides of the central benzene ring plane, and the distances between the coordinated imidazole N atom and the central benzene ring plane are larger than 1 Å; the trans-one: two of three imidazole groups are located above and below the central benzene ring plane, while the third imidazole ring is close to the benzene ring plane, and the distance between the coordinated imidazole N atom and central benzene ring plane is quite small; the cis,cis,cis-one: three imidazole groups are all located in the same side of the central benzene ring plane. The influences of the counteranion and coordination geometry of metal center on the structure of coordination polymers are discussed. Furthermore, the reversible anion exchange properties of 1 and 4 were investigated.

elements.content: All commercially available chemicals are of reagent grade and used as supplied without further purification. The ligand 1,3,5-tris(imidazol-1-ylmethyl)benzene (tib) was synthesized as reported previously. Elemental analyses of C, H, and N were measured on a Perkin-Elmer 240C elemental analyzer. FT-IR spectra were recorded on a Bruker Vector22 FT-IR spectrophotometer using KBr disks. Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) were performed on TA SDT 2960 instrument under flowing nitrogen with a heating rate of 10 °C min−1, and the TGA data of 1−7 are given in Figure S1 of the .
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

All commercially available chemicals are of reagent grade and used as supplied without further purification. The ligand 1,3,5-tris(imidazol-1-ylmethyl)benzene (tib) was synthesized as reported previously. Elemental analyses of C, H, and N were measured on a Perkin-Elmer 240C elemental analyzer. FT-IR spectra were recorded on a Bruker Vector22 FT-IR spectrophotometer using KBr disks. Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) were performed on TA SDT 2960 instrument under flowing nitrogen with a heating rate of 10 °C min-1, and the TGA data of 1-7 are given in Figure S1 of the .

elements.content: The complex was prepared by solvothermal reaction. A mixture of tib (12.8 mg, 0.04 mmol), Cu(NO3)2·4H2O (7.8 mg, 0.03 mmol), EtOH (6 mL), and H2O (6 mL) was sealed into a Teflon-lined autoclave and placed in an oven at 100 °C for 3 days; after slow cooling to room temperature, the blue block crystals were obtained with a yield of 70%. Anal. Calcd for C72H81.88N30O22.94Cu3 (1925.18): C, 44.92; H, 4.29; N, 21.83%. Found: C, 44.47; H, 4.63; N, 21.40%. IR (KBr pellet, cm−1): 3425 (s), 1613 (m), 1525 (m), 1439 (w), 1383 (s), 1290 (m), 1244 (m), 1109 (m), 1094 (m), 1035 (w), 950 (w), 740 (m), 660 (w). The TGA data of 1 showed an initial mass loss of 4.57% (calcd: 4.62%) from room temperature to 150 °C, representing the loss of the crystalline water molecules; the residue remains intact until it is heated to 240 °C, and then mass loss occurs in a consecutive step and does not stop until heating to 800 °C.

Anal. Calcd for C72H81.88N30O22.94Cu3 (1925.18): C, 44.92; H, 4.29; N, 21.83%. Found: C, 44.47; H, 4.63; N, 21.40%. IR (KBr pellet, cm-1): 3425 (s), 1613 (m), 1525 (m), 1439 (w), 1383 (s), 1290 (m), 1244 (m), 1109 (m), 1094 (m), 1035 (w), 950 (w), 740 (m), 660 (w). The TGA data of 1 showed an initial mass loss of 4.57% (calcd: 4.62%) from room temperature to 150 °C, representing the loss of the crystalline water molecules; the residue remains intact until it is heated to 240 °C, and then mass loss occurs in a consecutive step and does not stop until heating to 800 °C.

elements.content: The complex was prepared by a similar procedure as that for preparation of 1, except using CuSO4·5H2O (7.5 mg, 0.03 mmol) instead of Cu(NO3)2·4H2O to react with tib; blue block crystals were collected with 63% yield based on Cu. Anal. Calcd for C40H52N12O12S2Cu2 (1084.14): C, 44.32; H, 4.83; N, 15.50%. Found: C, 44.10; H, 5.07; N, 15.79%. IR (KBr pellet, cm−1): 3434 (m), 1609 (m), 1521 (s), 1435 (m), 1403 (w), 1337 (w), 1283 (w), 1243 (m), 1163 (s), 1135 (s), 1095 (s), 1029 (m), 945 (m), 844 (m), 737 (m), 659 (m). The TGA data show that 2 loses the crystal ethanol and water molecules from room temperature to 170 °C with observed weight loss of 8.10%, and the remaining polymeric structure was broken down above 280 °C and decomposition does not end until heating to 800 °C.

elements.content: The complex was prepared by the layering method. A buffer layer of ethanol and water (2:1, 8 mL) was carefully layered over an aqueous solution (2 mL) of Cd(NO3)2·4H2O (6.2 mg, 0.02 mmol), and then a solution of tib (12.8 mg, 0.04 mmol) in ethanol (4 mL) was layered over the buffer layer. After 4 weeks colorless block crystals suitable for X-ray diffraction analysis appeared, yield: 48%. Anal. Calcd for C36H44N14O10Cd (945.25): C, 45.74; H, 4.69; N, 20.75%. Found: C, 45.38; H, 4.86; N, 20.95%. IR (KBr pellet, cm−1): 3442 (s), 1612 (m), 1516 (m), 1442 (w), 1384 (s), 1358 (m), 1233 (m), 1106 (m), 1088 (m), 934 (w), 830 (w), 741 (m), 659 (m). The TGA data showed that 4 loses the lattice water molecules from room temperature to 155 °C with the observed mass loss of 8.16%, which is consistent with the theoretical value of 7.62%; the remaining polymeric structure was broken down above 325 °C, and decomposition does not end until heating to 800 °C.

Aqua-blue block crystals were collected in 67% yield based on Ni. Anal. Calcd for C20H30N6O8SNi (573.27): C, 41.91; H, 5.27; N, 14.66%. Found: C, 42.03; H, 5.18; N, 14.54%. IR (KBr pellet, cm-1): 3408 (s), 1612 (m), 1520 (s), 1441 (m), 1405 (w), 1372 (w), 1284 (m), 1240 (m), 1177 (m), 1110 (s), 1096 (s), 1048 (m), 972 (m), 943 (m), 835 (m), 769 (m), 661 (m). The TGA data exhibited that 7 was loss the solvent molecules in the temperature range of room temperature to 160 °C with observed mass loss of 16.93% (calcd 17.44%); the remaining structure was broken down above 395 °C, and decomposition does not end until heating to 800 °C.

elements.content: The data collections for 2 and 4 were carried out on Bruker Smart Apex CCD area-detector diffractometer using graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.710 73 Å) at 20(2) °C. The diffraction data were integrated by using the SAINT program. Semiempirical absorption corrections were applied using the SADABS program. All the structures were solved by direct methods, and all non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically on F 2 by the full-matrix least-squares technique using the SHELXL-97 crystallographic software package. Hydrogen atoms of the ligand tib in the structures were generated geometrically. The crystallographic data for 1, 3, 5, 6, and 7 were collected using a Rigaku RAXIS-RAPID imaging plate diffractometer at −73 °C with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.710 75 Å). The structures were solved by direct methods with SIR92 and expanded using Fourier techniques. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically by the full-matrix least-squares method on F 2. The hydrogen atoms except those of water molecules were generated geometrically. The hydrogen atoms of water molecules in 5−7 were located in a difference Fourier map and refined freely, while those of water molecules in 1, 2, and 4 could not be found from the difference Fourier map. In 1, the site occupancy factor of disordered water molecule of O3 was found to be 0.47, and the N3, O31, O32, and O33 atoms of the nitrate anion were highly disordered into three positions with site occupancy factors of 0.53, 0.29, and 0.18, respectively. All calculations were carried out on an SGI workstation using the teXsan crystallographic software package of Molecular Structure Corp. The details of the crystal parameters, data collection, and refinements for the complexes are summarized in Table ; selected bond lengths and angles with their estimated standard deviations are listed in Table .

The X-ray diffraction analysis showed that complex 1 crystallizes in the triclinic form with P1̅ space group, and the structure of 1 is shown in Figure a with atom numbering scheme. It is noteworthy that there are two independent Cu(II) centers with the same coordination environment but different bond lengths and angles and two ligands tib (A and B) with different conformations in the asymmetric unit of 1. Each Cu1 atom with square-planar coordination geometry is coordinated by four N atoms (N12, N12A, N32A, and N32B) from four different ligands B with N−Cu1−N bond angles in the range of 89.11(8)−180.0° and Cu1−N bond distances of 1.982(2) and 1.998(2) Å (Table ). Each Cu2 is coordinated by three imidazole N atoms (N112, N132A, and N152A) from three independent ligands A and one N42 atom from ligand B. The Cu2−N bond distances are in the range from 1.9973(19) to 2.021(2) Å. The Cu−N (imidazole) bond distances in 1 are comparable with those of reported Cu(II) complexes. On the other hand, each ligand A in 1 has a cis, trans, trans-conformation and acts as a tridentate linker using its three imidazole groups to coordinate with three Cu2 atoms. The distances between the coordinated N112, N132, and N152 atoms and central benzene ring plane are 3.19, 3.44, and 1.21 Å, respectively. If the coordination of Cu2 with N42 of ligand B is neglected, the Cu2 atoms are linked together by ligands A to give an infinite 1D chain A as shown in Figure b. It is notable that there are two kinds of 24-membered M2L2 macrocyclic rings A and B within the 1D chain; the Cu2···Cu2 separations are 12.31 and 8.60 Å within the rings A and B, respectively. Each ligand B also functions as a three-connector to bind with two Cu1 and one Cu2 atoms, but the conformation of ligand B is different from that of ligand A; the imidazole groups containing N32 and N42 atoms are located above and below the central benzene ring plane, and the distances between N32 or N42 atoms and benzene ring plane are 2.30 and 2.72 Å, respectively. However, the third imidazole group containing the N12 atom is nearly perpendicular to the central benzene ring plane with dihedral angle of 85.88°, the corresponding distance between the N12 atom and benzene ring plane is only 0.11 Å; this conformation of ligand B is defined as a trans- (Scheme ) rather than cis, trans, trans-one. Neglecting the coordination with Cu2 atom, each ligand B bridges two Cu1 atoms using its two flexible arms to generate an infinite 1D hinged chain B with M2L2 macrocyclic rings (Figure b), and the metal−metal distance of Cu1···Cu1A is 12.94 Å. The two benzene rings from two opposite ligands B within the M2L2 macrocyclic ring adopt a face-to-face orientation and are strictly parallel each other with a centroid−centroid distance of 4.94 Å. Two infinite chains A and B are connected together in ···ABAB··· alternated fashion through the coordination interaction of N42 with Cu2 to generate a 3D framework structure, as illustrated in Figure c.

elements.content: In order to investigate the effect of counteranion with different charge and coordination ability on the structure of the complexes, the reactions of tib with CuSO4·5H2O and CuCl2·2H2O were also carried out under the same reaction conditions as that for preparation of 1, and complexes 2 and 3 with different structures were successfully obtained. The crystal structure of 2 is shown in Figure a with the atom numbering scheme. Each asymmetric unit of 2 contains two distinct Cu(II) centers with different coordination environments, one tib and one sulfate anion. Each Cu(II) atom is sitting on an inversion center. The Cu1 atom is coordinated by four imidazole N atoms from four individual tib ligands with N−Cu1−N bond angles in the range 89.52(10)°−180.0° and Cu1−N bond distances of 1.998(2) and 2.034(2) Å (Table ). Therefore, the local coordination geometry around Cu1 atom can be regarded as square planar with a N4 donor set. The Cu2 atom is coordinated by two N atoms from two different tib ligands with N−Cu2−N bond angle of 180.0° and Cu−N bond distance of 1.984(3) Å. The two additional positions are occupied by two O atoms from two distinct sulfate anions with Cu2−O bond distance of 1.993(2) Å. It is clear that the Cu2 atom has similar square-planar coordination geometry as Cu1, but with a N2O2 rather than a N4 binding set. On the other hand, each tib serves as a tridentate ligand to bind with two Cu1 and one Cu2 atoms and adopts a cis, trans, trans-conformation since the distances between the each coordinated N2, N4, N6 atom and the central benzene ring plane are 3.07, 1.04, and 1.13 Å, respectively. The dihedral angles between each imidazole group and the central benzene ring plane are 66.31°, 75.84°, and 66.42°, respectively. The combination of the flexible tib ligands and four-coordinated Cu(II) atoms results in the formation of a 2D network with two different macrocycles A and B as illustrated in Figure b. In macrocyclic ring A, two tib ligands, each using two of its three flexible arms, link two Cu1 atoms to form a 24-membered ring with a Cu···Cu distance of 9.76 Å, while in the case of ring B, four tib ligands are connected by four Cu(II) atoms (two Cu1 and two Cu2) to generate a 48-membered ring with intermetallic separations of Cu1···Cu2 = Cu1A···Cu2A = 9.84 Å and Cu1···Cu2A = Cu1A···Cu2 = 14.48 Å.

elements.content: X-ray crystallographic analysis revealed that 3 belongs to monoclinic with space group of P21/c, and the asymmetric unit contains one Cu(II) center, one tib, and two coordinated chlorides. The crystal structure of 3 with atom numbering scheme is exhibited in Figure a. Each Cu(II) center is pentacoordinated by three imidazole N atoms from three different tib ligands with Cu−N bond lengths ranging from 1.9905(15) to 2.0493(16) Å and by two chlorides with Cu−Cl bond distances of 2.3218(8) and 2.4708(8) Å (Table ). The coordination geometry of Cu(II) atom can be described as trigonal bipyramid with a N3Cl2 donor set. The N12, Cl1, and Cl2 atoms consist of the equatorial plane and the apical position are occupied by the N32 and N52 atoms with N32−Cu−N52 bond angle of 175.06(6)°. On the other hand, each tib with cis, trans, trans-conformation serves as a tridentate ligand to coordinate with three Cu(II) atoms, and each Cu(II) atom bonds with three tib ligands with a T-form arrangement to give rise to a 2D rugate brick network in the bc plane, as illustrated in Figure b, in which there are two kinds of macrocyclic rings A and B, composed of two Cu(II) atoms and two ligands tib (each tib using two of its three arms) and four Cu(II) atoms and four ligands tib, respectively.

elements.content: In order to evaluate the influence of metal atoms on the structure of the complexes, reaction of tib with Cd(NO3)2·4H2O was performed, and complex 4 was successfully isolated. The X-ray crystallographic analysis indicates that 4 crystallizes in the monoclinic form with C2/c space group, and the asymmetric unit contains one Cd(II) atom sitting on an inversion center, one tib ligand, and one nitrate anion. The crystal structure of 4 is illustrated in Figure a with an atom numbering scheme. Each Cd(II) atom with slightly distorted octahedral coordination geometry is coordinated by six N atoms of imidazole groups derived from six different tib ligands; the bond lengths of Cd1−N2, Cd1−N4, and Cd1−N6 are 2.341(4), 2.371(4), and 2.392(4) Å, respectively, which are similar to those observed in other Cd(II) complexes. The N−Cd1−N bond angles are in the range from 85.88(12)° to 180.0° (Table ). On the other hand, each tib adopts a cis, trans, trans-conformation and acts as a tridentate ligand to coordinate with three different Cd(II) atoms. The distances between the coordinated N2, N4, and N6 atoms and the central benzene ring plane are 2.65, 2.54, and 2.50 Å, respectively. The dihedral angles between each of three imidazole groups and the central benzene ring plane are 73.37°, 89.72°, and 83.34°, respectively. Such a spatial conformation and coordination mode of the tib makes 4 a 3D framework structure with two different 1D channels A and B along the b-axis as exhibited in Figure b. It is interesting that nitrate anions and water molecules occupied the channel A, while the channel B is filled with water molecules. In addition, C−H···O hydrogen bonds were found between the O atoms of nitrate anions and the C atoms of ligand tib with C···O distances in the range from 3.232(14) to 3.528(10) Å and C−H−O angles varying from 139° to 162° ().

elements.content: Complexes 5−7 were synthesized by solvothermal reactions under the same conditions, their structures were determined by X-ray crystallography, and the results indicate that they have the same structure. Thus, as a typical example, only the structure of 5 is described in detail. The coordination environment around the Cd(II) in 5 is presented in Figure a with the atom numbering scheme. Each Cd(II) atom is coordinated by three N atoms from three different tib ligands in a T-form with Cd−N bond distances ranging from 2.274(2) to 2.321(3) Å. Three remaining coordination sites are occupied by three O atoms, two of which are from two coordinated water molecules and one is from a sulfate anion. The Cd−O bond distances are in the range from 2.338(3) to 2.368(3) Å, and O−Cd−O bond angles vary from 84.45(11)° to 172.86(9)° as listed in Table . Therefore, the local coordination geometry around the Cd(II) center can be regarded as a distorted octahedron with a N3O3 binding set. On the other hand, each tib takes a cis, cis, cis-conformation (Scheme ) and coordinates with three Cd(II) atoms. The three imidazole groups within each tib ligand are located in the same side and inclined to the central benzene ring plane with dihedral angles of 66.15°, 75.58°, and 86.33°, and the coordinated N12, N32, and N52 atoms locate above the central benzene ring plane with distances of 3.45, 3.26, and 1.66 Å, respectively. The dihedral angle between the plane composed of three coordinated N atoms and central benzene ring plane is 14.86°. It is interesting that two adjacent tib ligands link two Cd(II) atoms using two of its three flexible arms to generate an infinite 1D ladder which containing two different 24-membered M2L2 macrocyclic rings A and B (Figure b); the Cd···Cd distances within the M2L2 rings A and B are 7.16 and 8.73 Å, respectively.

elements.content: The most striking feature of 5 is that the neighboring 1D chains are further linked by one O2−H···O14 (sulfate anion) and five C−H···O (sulfate anion) hydrogen bonds to give rise to a 3D structure (Figure c). The uncoordinated water and ethanol molecules are located in the channels among the adjacent chains and held there via four intra- and intermolecular O−H···O hydrogen bonds (). It is clear that the intermolecular hydrogen bonds of sulfate anions play an important role in creating and consolidating the structure. Similar crystal structures and packing arrangements were found in the complexes 6 and 7 (Figures S3 and S4) in the .

elements.content: When the flexible tripodal ligand titmb reacts with CdSO4·8/3H2O by layering method using EtOH−H2O as solvent, complex [Cd3(titmb)2(SO4)4(H2O)2(EtOH)2][Cd(H2O)6]·2H2O with an unusual 2D stepwise structure was obtained. c It is noteworthy that the conformation of titmb in this complex is cis, trans, trans-, and the sulfate anion functions as bidentate bridging linker; however, in 5, the tib adopts a cis, cis, cis-conformation, and the sulfate anion acts as a terminal ligand to coordinate with Cd(II) atom. The structural difference between titmb and tib is just that there are three methyl groups at the 2, 4, 6-positions of the central benzene ring in titmb. The results showed that even subtle changes of the ligand may have great influence on the structure of the complexes.

elements.content: Seven transition metal(II) coordination polymers with flexible tripodal ligand tib were successfully synthesized and structurally characterized. The Cu(II) complexes 1−3 or Cd(II) complexes 4 and 5 were obtained by the reactions of tib and metal salts with different counteranions under the same reaction conditions, and the different structure of the complexes indicated that the counteranions with different size, charge, and coordination ability play an important role in the construction of coordination polymers with flexible ligand. In 1−3, the Cu(II) centers adopt square-planar or triangle-bipyramid coordination geometry, while in 4−7, the coordination geometries of Cd(II), Co(II), and Ni(II) centers are octahedral. The distinct structures of Cu(II) and Cd(II) complexes with the same counteranion implied that the metal centers with different coordination geometries have significant influence on the structure of the complexes. Complexes 5−7 were prepared under the same conditions and have the same counteranions; the central metal atoms adopt the same octahedral coordination geometry which leads to the formation of the same 1D chain structure. The results indicate that the metal atoms with the same coordination geometry do not affect the structure of complexes greatly. Because of the presence of three flexible arms, ligand tib can adopt different conformations and adjust its arm to meet the geometric requirement of the central metal atoms. In 1, two different conformations (cis, trans, trans - and trans-) of tib coexist, while in 2−4, tib adopts cis, trans, trans-conformation. In the case of 5−7, tib has a cis, cis, cis-conformation. The results attest that the flexible tripodal ligand tib can adopt different conformations and lead to the formation of a great variety of supramolecular frameworks.
elements.clean_text:
Comparison of the Structures

Seven transition metal(II) coordination polymers with flexible tripodal ligand tib were successfully synthesized and structurally characterized. The Cu(II) complexes 1-3 or Cd(II) complexes 4 and 5 were obtained by the reactions of tib and metal salts with different counteranions under the same reaction conditions, and the different structure of the complexes indicated that the counteranions with different size, charge, and coordination ability play an important role in the construction of coordination polymers with flexible ligand. In 1-3, the Cu(II) centers adopt square-planar or triangle-bipyramid coordination geometry, while in 4-7, the coordination geometries of Cd(II), Co(II), and Ni(II) centers are octahedral. The distinct structures of Cu(II) and Cd(II) complexes with the same counteranion implied that the metal centers with different coordination geometries have significant influence on the structure of the complexes. Complexes 5-7 were prepared under the same conditions and have the same counteranions; the central metal atoms adopt the same octahedral coordination geometry which leads to the formation of the same 1D chain structure. The results indicate that the metal atoms with the same coordination geometry do not affect the structure of complexes greatly. Because of the presence of three flexible arms, ligand tib can adopt different conformations and adjust its arm to meet the geometric requirement of the central metal atoms. In 1, two different conformations (cis, trans, trans - and trans-) of tib coexist, while in 2-4, tib adopts cis, trans, trans-conformation. In the case of 5-7, tib has a cis, cis, cis-conformation. The results attest that the flexible tripodal ligand tib can adopt different conformations and lead to the formation of a great variety of supramolecular frameworks.

elements.content: The crystal structural analysis revealed that {[Cu3(tib)4](NO3)6·4.94H2O} n (1) features a 3D framework structure, and the nitrate anions are filled in the vacancies (). Furthermore, the coordination polymer of 1 is insoluble in water and common organic solvents; thus, the complex is expected to have anion exchange property. Well-ground powder of 1 was suspended in the aqueous solution of NaClO4 and stirred for 1 day to allow anion exchange; the exchanged product {[Cu3(tib)4](ClO4)6} n (1A) was obtained (see ). The FT-IR spectra of 1 and the exchanged products are exhibited in Figure . It can be seen clearly that the intense bands around 1107 and 1121 cm−1, which originates from the ClO4 − anion, appeared in the spectrum of 1A, while the intense bands around 1383 and 1345 cm−1 of the NO3 − anion disappeared. It indicates that the NO3 − anions in the voids of 1 were completely exchanged by ClO4 − anions. The solid 1A was suspended in the solution of NaNO3 with constant stirring to allow reverse anion exchange, and the product 1B was obtained. The band of NO3 − appeared in the spectrum of 1B, and the bands of ClO4 − anion disappeared. The weak bands around 1109 and 1094 cm−1 in the spectra of 1 and 1B are assigned to the imidazole ring stretching vibrations. Furthermore, the results of the elemental analyses also confirmed the complete anion exchanges.

elements.content: The complex {[Cd(tib)2](NO3)2·4H2O} n (4) also has a 3D framework structure, and the nitrate anions are filled in the 1D channels A (Figure b). The anion exchange experiments of 4 were performed, and the results indicated that 4 has reversible anion exchange property. Excess NaClO4 or NaNO2 was added to a suspension of powdered 4 in water at room temperature, and the mixture was stirred for 1 day; the exchanged products {[Cd(tib)2](ClO4)2} n (4A) and {[Cd(tib)2](NO2)2} n (4B) were obtained. The FT-IR spectra of 4 and the exchanged products 4A or 4B are shown in Figure S5 or S6 of the , respectively. It is clear that the intense bands of 1088, 1106, and 1120 cm−1, which originate from the ClO4 − anion, appeared in the spectrum of exchange product 4A, and the intense bands at 1237 and 1270 cm−1 of the NO2 − anion are present in the spectrum of 4B, while the intense bands around 1384 and 1358 cm−1 of the NO3 − anion disappeared in the spectra of the exchanged products 4A and 4B. Namely, the NO3 − anions in the 3D framework of 4 were entirely exchanged by ClO4 − or NO2 − anions. To investigate the reversibility of the anion exchange of 4, the well-powdered 4A or 4B was added to an aqueous solution of NaNO3, and the mixture was stirred constantly at room temperature for 1 day. The resulting solids {[Cd(tib)2](NO3)2} n 4C or 4D were obtained. The intense band of NO3 − anion appeared again in the spectra of 4C and 4D, and the ClO4 − bands in the spectrum of 4C and NO2 − bands in the spectrum of 4D all disappeared. The results indicate that 4 has reversible anion exchange property.

Excess NaClO4 or NaNO2 was added to a suspension of powdered 4 in water at room temperature, and the mixture was stirred for 1 day; the exchanged products {[Cd(tib)2](ClO4)2} n  (4A) and {[Cd(tib)2](NO2)2} n  (4B) were obtained. The FT-IR spectra of 4 and the exchanged products 4A or 4B are shown in Figure S5 or S6 of the , respectively. It is clear that the intense bands of 1088, 1106, and 1120 cm-1, which originate from the ClO4 - anion, appeared in the spectrum of exchange product 4A, and the intense bands at 1237 and 1270 cm-1 of the NO2 - anion are present in the spectrum of 4B, while the intense bands around 1384 and 1358 cm-1 of the NO3 - anion disappeared in the spectra of the exchanged products 4A and 4B. Namely, the NO3 - anions in the 3D framework of 4 were entirely exchanged by ClO4 - or NO2 - anions. To investigate the reversibility of the anion exchange of 4, the well-powdered 4A or 4B was added to an aqueous solution of NaNO3, and the mixture was stirred constantly at room temperature for 1 day. The resulting solids {[Cd(tib)2](NO3)2} n  4C or 4D were obtained. The intense band of NO3 - anion appeared again in the spectra of 4C and 4D, and the ClO4 - bands in the spectrum of 4C and NO2 - bands in the spectrum of 4D all disappeared. The results indicate that 4 has reversible anion exchange property.

elements.content: A series of metal−organic coordination polymers with flexible tripodal ligand 1,3,5-tris(imidazol-1-ylmethyl)benzene (tib) have been synthesized and structurally characterized. The results demonstrate that the nature of counteranions and metal centers with different coordination geometry have a remarkable influence on the self-assembly of the flexible ligand with metal atoms and result in coordination architectures with different structures.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

A series of metal-organic coordination polymers with flexible tripodal ligand 1,3,5-tris(imidazol-1-ylmethyl)benzene (tib) have been synthesized and structurally characterized. The results demonstrate that the nature of counteranions and metal centers with different coordination geometry have a remarkable influence on the self-assembly of the flexible ligand with metal atoms and result in coordination architectures with different structures.

elements.content: The ligand tib with three flexible arms can adjust its configuration comfortably to meet the geometric requirement of the central metal atoms and result in a variety of fascinating coordination polymers. In 1−7, the tib ligands adopt three different types of conformations, namely, cis, trans, trans-, trans- and cis, cis, cis-conformations. Furthermore, the reversible anion exchange properties of 1 and 4 were investigated.

The complex was prepared by solvothermal reaction. A mixture of tib (12.8 mg, 0.04 mmol), Cu(NO3)2·4H2O (7.8 mg, 0.03 mmol), EtOH (6 mL), and H2O (6 mL) was sealed into a Teflon-lined autoclave and placed in an oven at 100 °C for 3 days; after slow cooling to room temperature, the blue block crystals were obtained with a yield of 70%. Anal. Calcd for C72H81.88N30O22.94Cu3 (1925.18): C, 44.92; H, 4.29; N, 21.83%. Found: C, 44.47; H, 4.63; N, 21.40%. IR (KBr pellet, cm−1): 3425 (s), 1613 (m), 1525 (m), 1439 (w), 1383 (s), 1290 (m), 1244 (m), 1109 (m), 1094 (m), 1035 (w), 950 (w), 740 (m), 660 (w). The TGA data of 1 showed an initial mass loss of 4.57% (calcd: 4.62%) from room temperature to 150 °C, representing the loss of the crystalline water molecules; the residue remains intact until it is heated to 240 °C, and then mass loss occurs in a consecutive step and does not stop until heating to 800 °C.

Synthesis of {[Cu<sub>2</sub>(tib)<sub>2</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub>]·2EtOH·2H<sub>2</sub>O}<sub> <italic toggle="yes">n</italic> </sub> (<bold>2</bold>)

The complex was prepared by a similar procedure as that for preparation of 1, except using CuSO4·5H2O (7.5 mg, 0.03 mmol) instead of Cu(NO3)2·4H2O to react with tib; blue block crystals were collected with 63% yield based on Cu. Anal. Calcd for C40H52N12O12S2Cu2 (1084.14): C, 44.32; H, 4.83; N, 15.50%. Found: C, 44.10; H, 5.07; N, 15.79%. IR (KBr pellet, cm−1): 3434 (m), 1609 (m), 1521 (s), 1435 (m), 1403 (w), 1337 (w), 1283 (w), 1243 (m), 1163 (s), 1135 (s), 1095 (s), 1029 (m), 945 (m), 844 (m), 737 (m), 659 (m). The TGA data show that 2 loses the crystal ethanol and water molecules from room temperature to 170 °C with observed weight loss of 8.10%, and the remaining polymeric structure was broken down above 280 °C and decomposition does not end until heating to 800 °C.

Synthesis of [Cu(tib)Cl<sub>2</sub>]<sub> <italic toggle="yes">n</italic> </sub> (<bold>3</bold>)

The complex was also prepared solvothermally in a Teflon-lined autoclave by heating a mixture of tib (12.8 mg, 0.04 mmol), CuCl2·2H2O (5.1 mg, 0.03 mmol), EtOH (7 mL), and H2O (3 mL) at 100 °C for 3 days; after slow cooling to room temperature, the blue block crystals were obtained in ca. 57% yield based on Cu. Anal. Calcd for C18H18N6Cl2Cu (452.82): C, 47.74; H, 4.01; N, 18.56%. Found: C, 47.58; H, 4.36; N, 18.44%. IR (KBr pellet, cm−1): 3442 (s), 1613 (m), 1518 (s), 1440 (m), 1400 (w), 1360 (w), 1278 (m), 1229 (m), 1097 (s), 1085 (s), 1024 (w), 948 (m), 840 (m), 739 (m), 658 (m). The TGA data of 3 exhibited that the mass loss occurs in a consecutive step and not stop until heating to 800 °C.

Synthesis of {[Cd(tib)<sub>2</sub>](NO<sub>3</sub>)<sub>2</sub>·4H<sub>2</sub>O}<sub> <italic toggle="yes">n</italic> </sub> (<bold>4</bold>)

The complex was prepared by the layering method. A buffer layer of ethanol and water (2:1, 8 mL) was carefully layered over an aqueous solution (2 mL) of Cd(NO3)2·4H2O (6.2 mg, 0.02 mmol), and then a solution of tib (12.8 mg, 0.04 mmol) in ethanol (4 mL) was layered over the buffer layer. After 4 weeks colorless block crystals suitable for X-ray diffraction analysis appeared, yield: 48%. Anal. Calcd for C36H44N14O10Cd (945.25): C, 45.74; H, 4.69; N, 20.75%. Found: C, 45.38; H, 4.86; N, 20.95%. IR (KBr pellet, cm−1): 3442 (s), 1612 (m), 1516 (m), 1442 (w), 1384 (s), 1358 (m), 1233 (m), 1106 (m), 1088 (m), 934 (w), 830 (w), 741 (m), 659 (m). The TGA data showed that 4 loses the lattice water molecules from room temperature to 155 °C with the observed mass loss of 8.16%, which is consistent with the theoretical value of 7.62%; the remaining polymeric structure was broken down above 325 °C, and decomposition does not end until heating to 800 °C.

Synthesis of {[Cd(tib)(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>2</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)]·EtOH·H<sub>2</sub>O}<sub> <italic toggle="yes">n</italic> </sub> (<bold>5</bold>)

The complex was obtained by a similar procedure as that for preparation of 4, except using CdSO4·8/3H2O (5.1 mg, 0.02 mmol) instead of Cd(NO3)2·4H2O. Colorless block crystals were collected after 3 weeks with 63% yield based on Cd. The crystals of 5 also can be prepared by solvothermal reaction using EtOH−H2O as solvent. Anal. Calcd for C20H30N6O8SCd (626.96): C, 38.31; H, 4.82; N, 13.40%. Found: C, 38.15; H, 4.94; N, 13.57%. IR (KBr pellet, cm−1): 3508 (s), 1620 (m), 1523 (s), 1442 (m), 1403 (w), 1348 (m), 1294 (w), 1236 (m), 1113 (s), 1034 (m), 948 (m), 866 (m), 754 (m), 659 (m). The TGA data of 5 show a weight loss of 14.40% (calcd 15.96%) from room temperature to 260 °C representing the loss of one ethanol, one crystal, and two coordinated water molecules; no further weight loss was observed before about 355 °C.

Synthesis of {[Co(tib)(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>2</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)]·EtOH·H<sub>2</sub>O}<sub> <italic toggle="yes">n</italic> </sub> (<bold>6</bold>)

The complex was prepared solvothermally in a Teflon-lined autoclave by heating a mixture of tib (12.8 mg, 0.04 mmol), CoSO4·7H2O (5.6 mg, 0.02 mmol), EtOH (7 mL), and H2O (4 mL) at 100 °C for 3 days; after the mixture was cooled to room temperature, pink block crystals were collected, yield: 58% based on Co. Anal. Calcd for C20H30N6O8SCo (573.49): C, 41.89; H, 5.27; N, 14.65%. Found: C, 41.73; H, 5.36; N, 14.52%. IR (KBr pellet, cm−1): 3420 (s), 1613 (m), 1518 (s), 1442 (m), 1404 (w), 1372 (w), 1284 (w), 1237 (m), 1111 (s), 1092 (s), 941 (m), 833 (m), 746 (m), 659 (m). The TGA data of 6 show an initial mass loss of 16.40% (calcd 17.45%) from room temperature to 135 °C, which is attributed to the elimination of the crystal solvent molecules; the residue was began to decompose above 360 °C.

Synthesis of {[Ni(tib)(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>2</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)]·EtOH·H<sub>2</sub>O}<sub> <italic toggle="yes">n</italic> </sub> (<bold>7</bold>)

The complex was prepared by a similar procedure as that for preparation of 6, except using NiSO4·6H2O (5.6 mg, 0.02 mmol) instead of CoSO4·7H2O. Aqua-blue block crystals were collected in 67% yield based on Ni. Anal. Calcd for C20H30N6O8SNi (573.27): C, 41.91; H, 5.27; N, 14.66%. Found: C, 42.03; H, 5.18; N, 14.54%. IR (KBr pellet, cm−1): 3408 (s), 1612 (m), 1520 (s), 1441 (m), 1405 (w), 1372 (w), 1284 (m), 1240 (m), 1177 (m), 1110 (s), 1096 (s), 1048 (m), 972 (m), 943 (m), 835 (m), 769 (m), 661 (m). The TGA data exhibited that 7 was loss the solvent molecules in the temperature range of room temperature to 160 °C with observed mass loss of 16.93% (calcd 17.44%); the remaining structure was broken down above 395 °C, and decomposition does not end until heating to 800 °C.

Procedures for Reversible Anion Exchange Reactions of <bold>1</bold> and <bold>4</bold>

A well-ground powder of complex {[Cu3(tib)4](NO3)6·4.94H2O} n (1) (50 mg) was suspended in an aqueous solution (5 mL) of NaClO4 (1.0 g), and the mixture was well stirred for 1 day at room temperature; then the solid was separated by centrifuging, washed with water several times, and dried in vacuum to give exchanged product {[Cu3(tib)4](ClO4)6} n (1A). Anal. Calcd for 1A (C72H72N24O24Cl6Cu3): C, 41.96; H, 3.52; N, 16.31%. Found: C, 41.58; H, 3.83; N, 16.19%. To investigate the reversibility of such anion exchange procedure of 1, the exchanged solid 1A was suspended in water (5 mL) and NaNO3 (1.0 g) was added. The mixture was stirred for 1 day, and then handled as the above procedure; the reverse exchanged product {[Cu3(tib)4](NO3)6} n (1B) was obtained. Anal. Calcd for 1B (C72H72N30O18Cu3): C, 47.10; H, 3.95; N, 22.88%. Found: C, 46.45; H, 3.78; N, 22.53%.
